1[Ἐπ]ὶ Ἡρα[κλείου τοῦ δεῖνα]
2Ἀρτέ[μιτι καί ---]
3γυμνασ̣[ίαρχοι ---]
4Ἀρχέδα̣[μος ---]
5Νυμφο̣[δώρου? ---]
6[Π]ο̣λύκλ̣[ειτος ---]
7[τοῦ δεῖνα]
Decree in honour of a gymnasiarch
The text, occupying 47 lines, fills the upper two-thirds of the main rectangular portion of the stele.

The lettering is tight, both in between letters and in interlinear spaces. The first two lines are larger and more spaced, though not necessarily more precise in execution. Alpha appears with both a straight and a curved crossbar. Interchangeable use of four-bar and lunate sigma, often in the same line, often close together. Interchangeable use of square and lunate epsilon, same variability and position as with sigma. There is occasional omission of the middle bar of a lunate epsilon, particularly in between two sigmas, resulting visually in the combination CCC. This occurs both at the beginning and end of lines, and does not seem to correspond to textual cues. Omega is mostly rhomboid or ovoid, occasionally round, though the few round instances seem to be an execution issue with the ovoid variant rather than a stylistic choice.
(Later) second or first century BCE (Dubois and Cordiano suggest 1st cent. BCE)
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo M. Metcalfe, 2016-09-27.

1[Τ]εβέριον Λ[---]-
2[υἱὸ]ν Διόγνη[τον? γυμνασιαρχ-]
3ήσαντα ΣΕ [---]
Seven lines of Greek letters, filling the face, with a regular left margin, the final line approximately centred; the text is engraved by means of individual dots punched with a rounded tool.

Regular neatly cut letters, with pronounced terminations to the strokes. Alpha has broken bar; beta a much smaller upper eye, just closed; epsilon has nearly equal strokes; zeta formed by vertical with horizontal top and bottom; kappa has shortened arms; mu has midstrokes descending only half-way, curved rather than angular, and not always reaching the top of the verticals; xsi formed by three horizontals only, the middle one shorter; omicron is full size; pi has horizontal extending beyond the verticals; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; phi is standard height, with ovoid eye; omega is closed, and tear-drop shaped.
Later second or earlier first century BCE

Text is engraved in the upper left corner of the front face of the stele; the text is incomplete on the right sides as the right upper corner is lost; however there is clear vacat below.

Letters of the mid-Hellenistic period: epsilon has short middle bar; omicron is small and mid-line; mu has vertical first and last strokes, the mid-point descends half-way; alpha is formed with both broken and straight bar; sigma has approximately parallel top and bottom strokes; omega is open; theta formed with a central point.

1Ε[ἰς Κ]αίσαρα Αὔγουστον φλάμενος Λουκίου Ἐγνατίου [Λ]ου̣[κί]ου υἱοῦ Γαλ̣(ερίᾳ)[---]
2(vac.)[---]δυῶν δὲ ἀ[νδ]ρῶν
3Σέξτου Ἐ[να]τ̣ί̣ου̣ Σ[έ]ξ[τ]ο[υ υἱοῦ Ῥ]ούφου
4Λούκιος [. 5.]ς Λουκίου υἱὸ[ς..]ο[---γυμνασίαρχος τῶν τε ἐφήβων καὶ νε]ωτέρων τοὺς ἀν[κ]λίτας ἐκ τῶν ἰδίων Ἑρμᾶι καὶ Ἡρακλε[ῖ]
Inscription recording the neaniskoi of the gymnasium

The text fills the face available below the cornice (and seems likely to have continued below), with probably a consistent left margin, but a less regular right margin, and some cramping in order to fit words/phrases to the line (as e.g. in line 1).

The letters are mostly regular with a fairly square module and terminal points to the strokes rather than serifs. Alpha has broken cross-bar; epsilon has nearly equal bars; zeta in the form of an I with broad crossbars; kappa has short arms; mu has sloping outer strokes and half-height mid-strokes; omicron is nearly full-size, and consistently has a central dot (in lines 2 and 3 appears to have a line underneath); rho has rounded closed eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes, and the mid-strokes extend almost the full width; phi is standard height, elliptical; omega is consistently a closed circle (without the central dot of omicron), sometimes on the baseline, sometimes traversed by the line.
Photo J. Prag, 29.06.2016, with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana

1Γυμνασιάρχης
2Εὐβουλίδας
3Ἡρακλείου

The text is engraved on the upper surface of the stone (a second text on the front face); a large circular hole intrudes into the first visible line of the text, and the stone is broken away on the right side of the upper part, so the original extent of the text is unclear, but there appears to be a vacat after the third visible line

Plain letters of the middle Hellenistic period: Pi has verticals of equal length; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; omicron is small and mid-line; epsilon has a short middle stroke; mu has vertical first and last strokes, while the middle point only descends part way; alpha has both broken and straight bar
